Title: Adoption rate of 58 innovative soil management practices
Abstract: The dataset is based on survey national experts in soil sciences. The survey aimed, among other, to identify the current level of adoption of a list of 58 soil management practices in the different countries and Environmental Zones across Europe of partners countries or regions, following the classification of Rogers (2003). In detail, five qualitative classes were defined: - only by a few farmers (e.g., the innovators) (approx. < 2.5% of farmers) - by the early adopters (approx. < 16% of farmers) - by an early majority (approx. < 50% of farmers) - by a late majority (approx. <84% of farmers) - by all farmers (approx. 100% of farmers) The list of 58 soil management practices was established in a preliminary inventory done in the framework of i-SoMPE : A preliminary list of well-documented Soil Management Practices (SMPs) was set up by reviewing published articles and reports from specific European Research projects, also including deliverables from the EJP SOIL programme. A preliminary check of the type and characteristics of each of SMPs was done in order to avoid to repeat twice the same practice in the inventory list of SMPs. After completing the preliminary check, a total of 58 SMPs were selected and briefly described. According to the EJP SOIL classification, they were grouped in 7 land management categories as follows: - agricultural systems, - buffer strips and small landscape elements, - crop protection, - crops and crop rotations, - organic matter and nutrient management,  - tillage and trafic, - water management The data were processed and crossed with the shapefiles of the agroecological zones (AEZ) for producing maps of adoption (!! not based on statistics). These maps are published in the report and will be shared online in image files in the i-SoMPE Community on Zenodo (https://zenodo.org/communities/i-sompe/?page=1&size=20) and through an public web application References, Rogers, Everett M. 2003. Diffusion of Innovations. 5th ed. New York, NY [u.a.]: Free Press.
Source: Frederic Vanwindekens, Olivier Heller, Claudia Di Bene, & Pasquale Nino. (2022). Adoption rate of 58 innovative soil management practices (maps of inventory A) (1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.6510954
Lineage: The origin of the data is a survey among partners of the EJP SOIL project (linked to national experts in agricultural soil). Frederic Vanwindekens processed the data set with supervision of colleagues and projects co-leaders.
Processing steps: All data were processed in R for formatting the data. For each country, in marginal Environment Zones the same adoption rate of a SMP was assigned as for the neighbouring documented zones. This ex-post analysis was done automatically using a script that can be consulted in annex F.2.
Citation: Frederic Vanwindekens, Olivier Heller, Claudia Di Bene, & Pasquale Nino. (2022). Adoption rate of 58 innovative soil management practices (maps of inventory A) (1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.6510954
Spatial resolution: (raw data linked to a vector layer)
Quality statement: It must be very clear that it is the perception of actual implementation by national experts (and not data from national statistics), as it was explained in the i-Sompe report

Title: Agroecological Zones of Europe used for i-SoMPE
Abstract: This dataset was compiled in the i-SoMPE Project of EJP SOIL in 2021 and 2022. This dataset contains information to characterize the agroecological zones (AEZ) of Europe on 4 spatial levels. The data was calculated by an R project available on GitLab (https://gitlab.com/heoi/i-sompe-wp1) using various data on land use, climate, soil characteristics and slope. More information on the data can be found in the report of the i-SoMPE project. The dataset contains the following files: - 1 ZIP-Folder with a shapefile of the AEZs used in i-SoMPE and described in the dataset - 1 XLSX file with information on all 4 spatial levels - 4 CSV files with information on 1 of 4 spatial levels - 1 XLSX file that contains information on the attributes described in the dataset
Source: Metzger, Marc J. (2018). The Environmental Stratification of Europe, [dataset]. University of Edinburgh. https://doi.org/10.7488/ds/2356.
Lineage: The generation of the data is described in the WP1 Report of the i-SoMPE Project (EJP SOIL) and on gitlab: https://gitlab.com/heoi/i-sompe-wp1
Processing steps: An Intersection of Environmental zones by Metzger and NUTS-0 Borders (except for Belgium) was produced to delineate Agro-Ecological Zones (AEZ).
Citation: Olivier Heller. (2022). Characterization of the Agroecological Zones of Europe (1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.6473232
Quality statement: The description of the AEZ includes  statistics on climate ans well as frequencies on land-use, organic soils, WRB soil types, soil texture, soil gravel content, soil rooting depth, soil water regime and slope. The information for this statistics were sourced from various sources listed in the documentation.

Title: Long term climatic data for i-SoMPE
Abstract: These maps were created for the i-SoMPE project within EJP SOIL in 2021 and 2022. They were used to calculate various climatic variables for the characterization of the Agro-Environmental Zones (AEZ) of Europe and to assess the potential area of application of soil managament practices. The input data was long term average (1991 - 2020) climatic data (min. temp., max. temp., mean. temp., ET0, Prec.) for every day of the year for every Agri4Cast grid cell. We calculated 11 climatic variables: meanTemp: Mean annual temperature meanPrec: Mean annual precipitation sum meanET0: Mean annual potential evapotranspiration sum GrowSeason: Average length of the growing season (number of days per year with average temperature above 5C) GrowSeason_class: Classification of the length of the growing season: < 200 days short; 200 to 300 days intermediate; >300 days long (Metzger et al., 2012) TempSum :Average annual temperature sum (sum of all average daily temperatures above 0C) TempSum_class: Classification of the temperature sum: < 2000 C = cold; 2000 to 3000 C = cool temperate; 3000 to 4000 C = temperate; 4000 to 5000 C = warm temperate; > 5000 C = hot (Metzger et al., 2012) HeatDay: Average number of heat days (number of days per year with average maximal temperature above 30C) FrostDay: Average number of frost days (number of days per year with average minimal temperature below 0C) WaterBalance: Mean annual water balance (meanPrec meanET0) DryDay: Average number of days per year with a negative water balance (Prec ET0) Sources: Agri4Cast: https://agri4cast.jrc.ec.europa.eu/DataPortal/Index.aspx Metzger et al., 2012: https://edepot.wur.nl/197197
Keywords: climate; air temperature; precipitations; growing season; heat days; water balance; dry days
Lineage: The scripts for data processing are publicly available on gitlab: https://gitlab.com/heoi/i-SoMPE-WP1-Agri4Cast.git
Processing steps: The Agri4Cast data used was aquired from the JRC.
Citation: Olivier Heller. (2022). Zonal and raster data for i-SoMPE WP1 R Project (1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.6472390
